articles.headline: Fighting Over Gold in the Land of Dracula
articles.snippet: A small-time Romanian farmer counts powerful names among his backers in a land battle with a Canadian gold mining company.
articles.abstract: A small-time Romanian farmer counts powerful names among his backers in a land battle with a Canadian gold mining company.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSIA MONTANA, Romania — Eugen David, a small-time farmer with a chipped tooth and muddy boots in this obscure wrinkle of Transylvania, is an unlikely man to attract the attention of movie stars and moguls. But he counts Vanessa Redgrave, George Soros and Teddy Goldsmith among his backers in a land battle with a Canadian gold mining company.

articles.headline: Layoffs Imminent at Philadelphia Inquirer
articles.snippet: The paper is expected to announce that it will lay off 68 to 71 employees, or about 17 percent of the newsroom staff.
articles.abstract: The paper is expected to announce that it will lay off 68 to 71 employees, or about 17 percent of the newsroom staff.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Inquirer is expected to announce today that it will lay off 68 to 71 employees, or about 17 percent of the newsroom staff, just seven months after a group of local businessmen took over the newspaper and its sister publication, The Daily News.

articles.headline: Dollar’s Skid Puts a Glow on the Euro
articles.snippet: Countries with large dollar holdings are showing a new willingness to dump the dollar in favor of the rising euro.
articles.abstract: Countries with large dollar holdings are showing a new willingness to dump the dollar in favor of the rising euro.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dollar slumped yesterday and the euro climbed to a three-week high against the currency.

articles.headline: Sensing Opportunity in Dormitory Air
articles.snippet: Younger customers are at the forefront of a boom in air fresheners as companies pour money into advertisements making the products seem cool.
articles.abstract: Younger customers are at the forefront of a boom in air fresheners as companies pour money into advertisements making the products seem cool.
articles.lead_paragraph: College stinks. Just ask Emily Watson, a sophomore at Dartmouth, who sprays her dorm room once a week and her clothes two to three times a week with fresheners, usually in citrus or other fruity flavors.

articles.headline: It’s the Year to Keep an Eye on Paychecks
articles.snippet: The single biggest economic question of 2007 will probably be this: Will the surge in the paychecks of ordinary Americans continue?
articles.abstract: The single biggest economic question of 2007 will probably be this: Will the surge in the paychecks of ordinary Americans continue?
articles.lead_paragraph: Do you remember all those books from the 1980s and ’90s explaining why the United States couldn’t keep up with Japan? Once they were proved wrong, pundits came forth with a new batch of titles to explain why the American boom might last forever. The masterwork of the genre was “Dow 36,000.”

articles.headline: Google Answer to Filling Jobs Is an Algorithm
articles.snippet: Google, in typical eccentric fashion, has created an automated way to search for well-rounded candidates.
articles.abstract: Google, in typical eccentric fashion, has created an automated way to search for well-rounded candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif. — Have you ever made a profit from a catering business or dog walking? Do you prefer to work alone or in groups? Have you ever set a world record in anything?

articles.headline: Iraq to Review Hussein’s Execution
articles.snippet: Saddam Hussein was subjected to a battery of taunts by official Shiite witnesses and guards as he awaited his hanging.
articles.abstract: Saddam Hussein was subjected to a battery of taunts by official Shiite witnesses and guards as he awaited his hanging.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Jan. 2 — Iraq’s Shiite-led government said Tuesday that it had ordered an investigation into the abusive behavior at the execution of Saddam Hussein, who was subjected to a battery of taunts by official Shiite witnesses and guards as he awaited his hanging.
articles.byline: By John F. Burns and James Glanz
